title: Will India win the 2016 ICC World Twenty20 cricket tournament?
preds: You can close this question. India lost the semi-finals of the tournament. Answer : 0%
West Indies and England are through to the finals.
Wow, way to go, West Indies! Amazing.
India have lost their semi final to the West Indies
India is destroying West Indies right now and got to be a heavy favorite in the final.
Past India v/s WI results and past India v/s England results.
Raising p on England in the final
Considering India is playing at home, West Indies are  the underdog . India in the final seems like a safe bet. England vs. India in the final is a different story.
Upping slightly on England beating New Zealand

England just did India a huge favour by beating NZ in the first semi final. English batting line up has hit some impressive form with Roy, Root, Buttler all doing well in this tournament. I would now give 60% odds on India beating them in the final.
India qualifies for the semi finals where it faces West Indies, going by their past performance it appears India stands a very good chance of getting into the finals.
This is getting interesting. They still have to best NZ.
Through to the semi finals, which is knockout. Only NZ is undefeated, Bharat has 1 loss, and WI/ENG have 2 losses apiece. The Bookies give Bharat the best odds for winning.

My own judgement based on watching the teams so far gave India a 27% chance, considering them just slightly more likely to win the semifinal on 31 March. West Indies lost to Afghanistan, the lowest ranked team while India miraculously survived against Bangladesh, the other qualifier, who had looked 99% certain of winning till they apparently lost their heads in the last three balls.
India made it into semi-finals.  Proven their mettle.
Well, they're one of the four teams, so leaving them at 16% seems unwarranted.
India is the favorite out of the 4 teams with a shot
I would put odds as follows
I'm only able to follow the scores/commentary online, but that was a great comeback over Australia. I'm having way too much fun rooting for India, and will go all in with an unreasonable 100%

India are in the semi-finals after beating Australia in the last group match and are looking good enough to be favorites against the West Indies there. Any of the semi-finalists could win the tournament, though home advantage should count for India.

India need to win three matches. My estimation of their chance of beating:
Australia: 60%
West Indies: 70%
New Zealand/England: 70%
=.294
In order to win at this point, India would need to beat Australia, likely a 4-0 West Indies, and then perhaps a 5-0 New Zealand.  I don't favor the chances for a team that hasn't been batting well.
India had a somewhat difficult time with Pakistan. I will adjust after match 31 with Australia.

India has one more group match, which they must win to advance to the semi-finals i.e to win the tournament they have to win three in a row. Judging by performances so far, their chances of winning the last group match against Australia on Sunday are no  better than 60%. Their likely semi final opponents are the West Indies who have been playing well till now, so I'd say India's chances of beating them are 50% at best. If they get through to the finals, they could be up against New Zealand who beat them convincingly in their group match, so again 50% at best.
Won against Bangladesh but only narrowly.
They need three straight wins against teams that seem to be very capable of beating them. Bangladesh game was uninspiring. Dropping to 12, handwaving a 50% chance of each victory from here on out.

After the match against Bangladesh, they now need 3 back to back victories against the strongest teams in the tournament (starting with Australia for deciding which of the two gets into Semis). Bangla win was not at all convincing but somewhat paradoxically, I think such a close win boosts the confidence level and they will perform better in the remaining games.
looks like they are going into semi finals...

Mahendra Singh Dhoni hailed India as cricket's bounce  back kings after they again followed up an early defeat in a major tournament with an emphatic win and kick started their bid for World Twenty20 glory.
After their shock defeat on Tuesday to New Zealand in their first match, the hosts cruised to a six-wicket victory over arch rivals Pakistan in Kolkata late Saturday.
The defeat against New Zealand had put a question mark over India's status as red-hot favorites and triggered accusations of complacency.
But in a cauldron-like atmosphere of a packed Eden Gardens, Dhoni's men held their nerve and reached the target of 119 with 13 balls remaining.
Dropping this a bunch as they essentially have to win their last 2 matches just to qualify for the semi's, one against Australia.  Then they have would still have to win the semi's and finals.
There are many teams with equal talent out there. A single good performance over a short period can swing a T20 match.
Home advantage but no good bowling attack. Too reliant on Kohli firing in the batting lineup
Adjusting upward after winning the match with Pakistan.
Oh oh! India lost to New Zealand

And since the score of the aforementioned game was such a debacle, if relative scores matter in the final decision, India will have that against them also.

After an embarrassingly one-sided first game loss against NZ (definitely a top 2 team, against whom India has not yet won in 5 games!), India cannot afford another mistake in the group elimination stage. The odds of making the SF has gone down dramatically to 55%. Can't be assured of a win in SF either. Odds of that at 60%. Final stays at 50% for now.
Overall odds ->  17%
Downgrading a bit. First match may not mean much, especially against another top-3 team, but losses ought to be punished given that I had no real priors coming in.

In a stunning upset, India have lost the opening match to New Zealand, who were ranked 5th by the bookmakers. India should still reach the semi-finals though now they'll need to win against second favorites Australia to do so. Reducing my probability accordingly.

I was way too confident on India before. Updating in response to NZ loss, since I had priced in a pretty high chance of them winning. India may have to win the rest of their group stage matches to proceed now, as only 2/5 teams go through. This includes probably beating Australia.
Based on an average of betting odds, the number of teams capable of winning and world T20 rankings.

Indian team's winning streak of 11 games ended in the warm up game against South Africa. Admittedly, it cannot be counted as a real loss since the two in-form batsmen retired at 16th over to give batting experience to those coming lower down in the order. But I think it is clear that when playing South Africa, chances of India winning is only 50% (they lost the home T20 series too to SA recently).

Team is maintaining the winning momentum. Just won impressively against the Windies. Time to adjust my forecast.
Same logic as earlier, except I am now putting the odds of making SF at 80%, winning SF at 75% and winning F at 70%.
Overall at 42%.
India seem to be favoured vs. NZ by the books.  So far, so good, if it happens that way; may not, of course, which is why there are books.
90% chance of semifinal, 65% chance in semi and 60% chance in final

India is running high on confidence having won every one of the last ten T20 games it played. Also, beating Australia in Australia was about as good as it gets. But T20 is unpredictable and an unexpected loss is always on the cards, even with home advantage. The group stage is difficult as it allows only 2 teams to go through putting pressure on even the strong teams right at the start. 
I put the chance of qualifying for semis at 70%. Victory in SF at 65% and victory in Final at 60%. 
Taken together, I can't give better odds than about 27% at the start of tournament.

Realistically there are eight teams who could possibly win under any circumstances. Nobody who isn't a test playing nation is going to, so the base rate for these should be 12.5%. On top of this, India have home advantage. The IPL means their players are the most experienced in the format. I don't especially trust the ICC rankings for T20 internationals, due to lack of matches between tournaments in this format, but India are ranked number one, and have plenty of players ranked near the top. Every bookmaker currently has India as favourites to win.
India has a very tough side.

I don't know anything about cricket, but a team that isn't the consensus #1 in the world probably shouldn't be over 50% to win a 16-team tournament. One constant, in articles I've read about the T20, is that the type of cricket played in the tournament is "unpredictable", with a lot of room for randomness. This should lead to more evenness than we'd expect, given each team's respective strength, which further weakens India's chances.

Baseline is 6.25% if all teams had even odds (16 teams in tournament). Current betting odds show India at 100/30 which are the best odds in the field - second best odds at 11/2 for Australia and England. I did a rough calculation of odds available by country - 11 countries were shown with odds. Also looked at past winners - India finished 2nd in the last competition - I looked at countries that finished 2nd and how they did the next competition - Sri Lanka won after finishing 2nd and so did Pakistan back in 2009. Host nations haven't produced a winner in the past, no strong indicator of team performance; might be some added pressure from hosting.

I'm giving them slightly better chances than the bookmakers do. This is an unpredictable format, and 8 out of the 10 teams could justifiably be given at least a 10% chance of winning.

There are four usual suspects (title contenders) in any ICC world cricket championship - Australia, India, South Africa and Sri Lanka. 
IPL has given the key players (if not all playing 11) of all these countries enough experience in Indian conditions. So to start with, the base rate probability of each one  winning the title should be 25%. I would not read much into recent T-20 results especially in bi-lateral matches. South Africa mostly does well in these low stake matches while India does  better in world cups. On top of that, India's home support  give definite edge to India. 
That said, T20 remains the most difficult version to call. T20 world cups have produced 5 different winners in previous 5 editions. On the other hand, 4 out the past 5 50-over world cup tournaments have been won by Australia. So we can not ascribe significantly high probability to any one nation.
Now to maths:
India can advance to next stage (semi-final) by either winning the group or coming second. 

I estimate that India has 36% probability of winning the group and 45% of coming second. I have just considered one path to the top - winning all its matches. Similarly, there is 45% probability that India loses just one of its four matches which will ensure at least a second spot in the group. 
I know there could be other permutations also but that would only increase the probability (apart from increasing the complexity to calculate the odds).

Base rate is consensus: 25%. They are favourites with books (implied odds 7/2 - 11/4 22-26%).
ODI world cup: home winners are getting more common. (Australia and India recently). Indian pitches are distinctive. Countries seem to be getting worse at playing away. 
India have IPL so lots of experience. But lots of international players take part too.
The two factors above make me want to put the probability nearer 35%
Previous T20 world cups: India have won one of the five (the first in 2007 in SA). Came 2nd once in 2014. Sri Lanka have won once with two seconds. No team has won twice.
India ODI and T20 ranking: They are 2nd in the ODI rankings, but 8th(!!!) in the T20 rankings. This makes me want to lower the probability to below the base rate!
Recent T20 results: Lost 2-0 to SA at home. Drew 1-1 with Zim away.
They’ve only won one T20 series (a lone T20 in 2013/14 at home against Aus) going back to 2012. But long term form in T20 doesn’t really exist.
I think home advantage and conditions will prove vital. The Asian nations also have a warm up tournament. Some pundits are touting SA with their strong one day batting, but I think Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Australia and India are the best shouts. England and New Zealand probably don’t have the right talents for the conditions. 
Game theory makes me think I should stick my neck out and show some confidence in India, even though it’ll cost me if I’m wrong.
Take 5% of betting market as the weight of Indian optimism bias is probably distorting the market (c.f. England at World Cups)

With the best international players now taking part in the IPL the 'home-field' advantage is reduced and hence my 20% is reduced to a 15% as the West Indies, Australia, England, South Africa, Pakistan all field teams with players capable of grabbing any game.

Australia will probably win, because they have much better fielders. Their batsmen will also overpower India, if in good form. Indian batsmen are generally poor against fast bowlers, and Australia has a recovered James Pattinson, a very skilled fast bowler.

India are hosting - good track record when playing at home. Strong batting line up. Negatives - tough pool including New Zealand and Australia. Aging team. 20 / 20 is a short format - statistically poorer teams can do better than a 50 over 1 day game.

Of the top 10 teams India ranks 5th with a win % of 56. Home court advantage seems not to be significant for India.

Sitting pat on 45%. Turns out a Cricket fanatic I know was right about a few things.
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/30/sports/cricket/pakistan-cricket-mired-in-threefold-controversy.html?emc=edit_ee_20151230&nl=todaysheadlines-europe&nlid=70183565&_r=0
But it was doping that dealt a hammer blow Sunday, with potential consequences through 2016 and beyond. Pakistan’s star spin bowler, Yasir Shah, tested positive for the banned diuretic chlorthalidone and has been suspended while he goes through the International Cricket Council’s disciplinary procedures.

There are 16 teams consisting of 10 full members and 6 associate members. Associate members are considered weaker and had to qualify to progress to this stage of the tournament. Full members qualified automatically.
The top 8 full members have a bye past the first round and will be joined by the top 2 from the qualifying round which consists of the 8 weaker teams.
Therefore outside view says 10% chance of winning. (The weaker teams are a lot weaker - would be greatest upset in sport's history if one other than top 8 won; increase to 12%)
10 major teams participating. 10% probability India will win.

In their group they have a have a 50% chance of going through as there are 4 realistic prospects and 2 teams will advance. After that each match is 50/50 due to the short nature of the T20 format so, coupled with a reasonable home advantage and severe pressure pressure I have decreased my forecast to a 45% chance.

10 teams hence a 10% chance by default. Not sure of home advantage unless they make spinning tracks. SA really gave them a hard time recently on flat tracks in India. They also seem to be in the tougher group.
In a tournament with 10 teams, of which 8 can be considered realistic prospects to win the chances of a strong Indian side with home advantage can be stated as high as 20% but no more.

T20 results are as much a matter of chance as they're of skill so each team has a 50% chance. As the home side India has crowd support & are well adjusted to local conditions but also face unrealistic expectations that put them under greater stress - so I adjust the probability downwards a bit to 45%.
I believe it will be India or South Africa.  India has home field advantage, but South Africa seems better in head to head.

India are clear favourites to win the world cup, due to a couple of reasons. Firstly, it's played in India, which (similar to other sub-continent wickets) is known for its' spinning pitches. India has several high quality spinners such as Ashwin, Jadeja etc., along with several part timers such as Raina, Kohli etc. who can spin the ball as well. In addition to the obvious home advantage, the Indian team is well balanced and has an ideal balance for a twenty 20, with aggressive batsmen, top notch fast bowlers and reliable spinners. The team that may threaten India for the title is South Africa (which clobbered India in an ODI series recently). However, others such as Sri Lanka and Pakistan may surprise as well. Barring the threat of South Africa, I expect a sub-continent team to lift the trophy.

India are at home and one of 6 teams with a realistic chance of winning. Two qualify from their group and they face competition mostly from New Zealand and Australia - so probably a 70%-75% chance of qualifying. They then face matches against most likely South Africa, England or Sri Lanka - I would say a 50-60% chance of winning and then a 50:50 game against a finalist
It's group is too difficult, and the pressure will all be on India as host.  Cf. England in the Rugby World Cup!
Home team, but not consistent or good enough. But T20 needs luck as well as skill
They have been in 40% of finals and won 20% of previous events.  Bump to 30% for hosting.

India must come first or second in a pool including Australia, New Zealand, Pakistan and a minnow.  Getting higher than both Australia and New Zealand will be difficult enough - I give them 50/50 for that.  First semi will be against South Africa (a shoo-in to be first or second in their pool) or England/ Sri Lanka/ West Indies (good on any day, but to consistently put together a whole tournament...?  Doubtful) - I give them a 20% chance of winning that game.  Then the final will be against whoever is good enough to win the other semi - not looking good.

The best odds you can get are 7/2 (a 22.22% chance of winning) and the worst 5/2 (28.6%) and the statistical 'mode' seems to be 3/1 (or 25%).  Fair odds ought to add up to 100%, but typically add up to 120-135% even ignoring the no-hopers.  So everyone's chances of winning are overstated by one fifth to one third.  As a rule of thumb, favourites attract more money and so the market is better in that the odds are closer to the realistic outcome.  Hence a 3/1 favourite might only have its chances of winning overstated by 20%, not 30+%.  With 3/1 being the mode and average price for India to win, I subtract 20% of that as 'premium' and give them a 20% actual chance.

India has a great record against every other country, including all of its regional rivals (Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka) and Australia, as long as it is playing in India. The public's passion for cricket in India is incredibly high, and there have been studies conducted regarding the beneficial effects of an enthusiastic crowd on the physiology and mental outlook of athletes when they are playing in their home town or country.
